Far from the unsure direction of
Lincoln Gordon or the paternal
stewardship of Milton Eisenhower,
Steven Muller has begun in the past year
to provide a more deliberate sort of
leadership for Hopkins.

gained a hospital."

Philadelphia hit a workman-like
42% from the floor (47% in the
first half) while their host's

an incredible 23% in the first
half).

By CHUCK SLONIM
Last Saturday the Blue Jay
grapplers traveled to Towson to
wrestle the Tigers. They returned
with their second defeat in a row
24-1 5, Lowering their season
record to 6-3. Although
Saturday's score showed a much
better match than last year's 39-5
Blue Jay defeat, the Hopkins'
team went into the match
believing that they could pull out
a win.
With Towson pulling some
unexpected personnel changes,
the Tigers managed to beat the
Jays at Hopkin's strong-point,
which is to say, the co-captains,
Stevens and Hazard.
Ron Pucillo started things off
with a nice comeback from a 2-2
tie early in his match to defeat
his opponent 9-2. Pucillo put his
man on his back once and kept
control throughout the match.
Mike Privitera got caught off
his feet in the first period and
was put directly on his back and
pinned at 1:12. Clark Kingery,
who seems to be getting his old
form back, won his match 9-0
while his opponent stalled as not
to allow Kingery to get the fall.
Rob Fink, undefeated in four
matches, wrestled what his coach
termed "a very intelligent"
match. Fink won his match on
riding time 2-1.
Fred Goldman was matched
against last year's Maryland state
champion who proved as

formidable as his title. Goldman
was pinned at 4:00. Dave Mulock
lost 8-1 on three takedowns
during his match while co-captain
Craig Stevens lost to a man who
finished second in the state last
year.
Stevens, who was wresting
with bruised ribs didn't seem to
be up to par, which could be a
result of his injury in last week's
match with Lebanon Valley.
Although he had a takedown,
Stevens lost 10-4.
Wayne Panullo lost a decision
to a much more experienced
wrestler. Co-captain Neil Hazard
wrestled a man whom he had
beaten 3-2 last year and now
wrestles heavyweight for the
Tigers but dropped to 190
pounds especially to wrestle
Hazard. His opponent, who was
obviously much more psyched
for the match than Hazard,
defeated Neil 8-3.
Heavyweight Gary Murza
wrestled Towson's 190 pounder,
who with thirty seconds left in
the match was disqualified for
stalling.
Had both the Blue Jay
co-captains not been beaten, the
victory would probably have
been registered with the Hopkins'
team.
Tomorrow the Jays travel to
Westchester to compete against
Western Maryland, who defeated
Towson earlier in the season. The
match will begin at 3:00 P.M.

Gotwals serves two positions
By ROBERT FREUNDLICH
Harry Gotwals has a dual role
at Hopkins, that of wrestling
coach and assistant director of
the Annual Giving Fund. Gotwals
is a recent alumnus of Hopkins,
graduating in 1969 as a social and
behavioral science area major
with a concentration in psychology
After graduation, he taught math
and social science and coached
the wrestling team at Boys
Latin High School.
Spare Time
During his sparse spare time,
Go twals enjoys travelling,
scouting opponent wrestling
teams and corresponding to
applicants about .Hopkins';
wrestling program. Continuing
his schooling in the evening
school, he hopes to obtain at,
M .A. in Administrative Science.
Gotwals started wrestling in
1964 while a junior in high

school, and played on the
Hopkins team for three years.
Coach Gotwals enjoys wrestling
because it is "one of the most
demanding sports: it takes
strength, speed, agility, and tc
some extent mental toughness."
Because of his previous
association and subsequent
understanding of Hopkins, Coach
Gotwals is lenient on missing
practice for academic reasons.
According to Coach Gotwals,
"Academics come first;" hence
for example team members were
allowed to cut practice to see the
Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium, or to work in a
laboratory. He also doesn't cut
anyone, however "wrestling is a
difficult sport and requires some
weight loss, therefore only the
dedicated pursue it. As a result
there tend to be few third
stringers, unless they have

prospects of becoming a varsity
performer in the near future.
Besides being the Assistant
Director of the Anual Giving,
which entails running the alumni
roll call, Mr. Gotwals is also the
Parents Coordinator and Director
of Student Supports. As Parents
coordinator, he planned the
Parents' weekend in October.
That position also involves
compiling publications and
speaking at regional alumni
meetings. Seeking scholarships
from Baltimore business is a
function of his as Director of
Student Support. On Hopkins
financial situation, Gotwals said,
"If we depended completely
upon private money, we
wouldn't be here; however, we
don't want to rely completely on
government funding either, but
there is a happy medium which
we are approaching."
